sections.title: Stress and Your Brain
sections.content: Financial fear activates the amygdala, narrowing focus and reducing problem-solving capacity. Before you can think clearly about numbers, you need to calm the body. Stress reduction is not a luxury—it is a prerequisite for sound decisions.

points.title: Physical Tension
points.description: Tight shoulders, shallow breathing when checking balances.

points.title: Avoidance
points.description: Skipping bill reminders or refusing to open statements.

points.title: Catastrophic Thinking
points.description: Jumping from one late payment to imagining total financial collapse.

sections.title: Reset Protocol
sections.content: Name what you feel, move the body, then take one small action. Repeat until calm returns.

sections.title: Three-R System
sections.content: Regulate: Use breathwork or movement to calm your nervous system. Reframe: Challenge catastrophic thoughts with facts. Respond: Choose the next smallest step (e.g., email the creditor, check due dates, move $20 to savings).

sections.title: Financial Stress Triage
steps: Create a calming playlist, breathwork app shortcut, or short walk routine for immediate relief.
Write your top three money stressors and one fact-based statement to counter each.
List support resources—friends, mentors, financial counselors—you can contact within 24 hours.
Schedule a 30-minute finance focus block where you tackle one stressor using the Three-R system.
Set a weekly check-in reminder to monitor stress levels and preempt escalation.

sections.title: Stress Alarm
sections.content: Notice over-checking balances multiple times per day. When it happens, pause and switch to your regulation tool instead.
